dt: {bc}feeling or showing agitation, worry, annoyance, etc.

dt.t: Never had Johnny seen Rab so {wi}bothered{/wi} about anything as he was over his inability to get himself a good modern gun.
… insisted that there was really nothing to get all {phrase}hot and bothered{/phrase} {gloss}=angrily upset{/gloss} about.

shortdef: feeling or showing agitation, worry, annoyance, etc.

dt.t: {wi}bothered{/wi} by the itchy tag on his shirt

dt: {bc}to cause to be somewhat anxious or concerned

pt: {sc}annoy{/sc} {sc}vex{/sc} {sc}irk{/sc} {sc}bother{/sc} mean to upset a person's composure. {sc}annoy{/sc} implies a wearing on the nerves by persistent petty unpleasantness.
{sc}vex{/sc} implies greater provocation and stronger disturbance and usually connotes anger but sometimes perplexity or anxiety.

pt.t: {it}vexed{/it} by her son's failure to clean his room

pt: {sc}irk{/sc} stresses difficulty in enduring and the resulting weariness or impatience of spirit.
{sc}bother{/sc} suggests interference with comfort or peace of mind.

et: Early attestations strongly associate the word with Ireland, though if {it}bother{/it} is authentically Hiberno-English, the interdental consonant must be secondary, perhaps by association with earlier {et_link|pother:1|pother:1}, itself of obscure origin. A hypothetical link with Irish {it}bodhar{/it} "deaf, confused" is improbable given that the internal dental consonant in Irish was lost by 1300.
shortdef: to annoy especially by petty provocation : irk
to cause to be somewhat anxious or concerned —often used interjectionally
